gauzy: A "gauzy" thing is usually thin and transparent.
Gauzy material is usually light and airy, with a loose weave.
meshed: "Meshed" material typically looks like a screen or net.
A "meshed" texture is a type of textured fabric that has a tight, interwoven design.
cracked: A "cracked" texture looks like it has cracks in it.
A cracked pattern looks like a series of cracks or lines in the surface of the material.
stratified: Strata (layers) of sedimentary rock are usually visible in cliffs, road cuts, and quarry walls.
A "stratified" object is one that is layered, with each layer having a different composition from the ones above and below it.
scaly: A scaly texture can look smooth and shiny, or it can look dry and cracked.
A scaly surface is covered with small, hard pieces that look like scales.
swirly: A "swirly" surface usually has a lot of small, tight curves.
The term "swirly" is used to describe a texture that has a lot of movement and is often spiral-like in shape.
perforated: A perforated surface looks like it has small holes punched through it.
A perforated thing has small holes in it.
pleated: A pleated object has folds or creases in it.
A pleated texture has a series of parallel folds or creases.
flecked: Flecked material contains small flecks or pieces of another material mixed in with it.
A "flecked" pattern is one that is dotted or spotted with a different color or material.
fibrous: A fibrous thing is usually stringy or muscular in appearance.
One example of a fibrous thing is a piece of paper.
polka-dotted: A "polka-dotted" thing is typically an item of clothing with large, distinctively-colored dots on it.
A polka-dotted thing is typically an item of clothing or fabric that has small, round spots on it.
chequered: A "chequered" thing has a pattern of alternating light and dark squares.
A chequered surface has a regular pattern of squares or rectangles, usually in two different colors.
blotchy: A blotchy texture looks like it has tiny spots or bumps all over it.
There is no definitive answer to this question since the word "blotchy" is subjective.
stained: A stained object is one that is discolored by a substance.
There are many types of stains, but most are generally darker than the surrounding area and have irregular shapes.
crystalline: A crystalline material looks like a diamond or a crystal.
A crystalline surface is smooth and free of pits or other imperfections.
porous: A "porous" pattern has tiny holes or pores.
Porous materials have small holes throughout them.
banded: A banded surface is a surface that is made up of a series of bands, or stripes.
A "banded" object has horizontal or vertical bands of color.
lacelike: A lacelike object is typically a delicate and ornate fabric.
Lacelike material typically has a hole pattern that resembles that of a doily.
sprinkled: A sprinkling of materials looks like a light dusting or covering.
A "sprinkled" texture looks like a series of small dots or droplets.
bubbly: A bubbly pattern is a small cluster of bubbles that is surrounded by a larger cluster of bubbles.
Bubbly material looks foamy and full of bubbles.
lined: A lined surface has a definite boundary, beyond which there is nothing.
A lined pattern has a row of stitches running down the center of the fabric.
veined: Veined material has a network ofthin lines or streaks running through it.
A veined pattern is a pattern in which veins or lines radiate out from a center point.
bumpy: A bumpy texture can look like a lot of things.
A bumps pattern typically looks like a series of raised bumps or lines.
paisley: A paisley object looks like a decorative fabric with a pattern of curved shapes.
A paisley object looks like a decorative fabric with a pattern of curved shapes.
potholed: A "potholed" texture is rough, uneven, and full of holes.
waffled: A waffled texture looks like a series of small squares.
The term "waffled" can mean two different things.
pitted: Pitted textures can appear smooth overall, but have tiny pits or indentations spread throughout.
A pitted material has small indentations or holes on its surface.
frilly: A "frilly" object is usually an object that is very ornate or detailed.
When a pattern is frilly, it has a lot of small details that make it look decorative.
spiralled: Spiralled material is material that is coiled or twisted together in a spiral shape.
A spiralled surface looks like a surface with a lot of twists and turns.
knitted: Knitted material looks like a series of loops that have been created by interlocking yarn.
Knitted objects are usually made up of a series of interlocking loops of yarn.
grooved: A grooved surface is a surface with a series of parallel lines running along it.
A grooved thing usually has a long, narrow depression running along its length.
dotted: A dotted object looks like it has dots on it.
A dotted surface looks like it has a lot of small dots on it.
interlaced: Interlaced material appears to have a series of curved lines running through it.
If you are talking about an interlaced television signal, it looks like a fuzzy picture.
crosshatched: "Crosshatched" material usually has a pattern of repeated, intersecting lines.
Crosshatched textures have a crisscross pattern.
wrinkled: A wrinkled material looks like it has been folded or creased.
A wrinkled object is an object that has folds or creases in it.
smeared: A smeared pattern looks like a series of lines or bars that are close together.
striped: A striped fabric has parallel lines of different colors running the length of the fabric.
Striped material usually has alternating bands of color running horizontally or vertically.
braided: A "braided" texture is defined by small, thin strands of material that are intertwined with each other.
A braid is a complex structure made of three or more strands of hair, fabric, or other material interwoven together.
freckled: A "freckled" surface is one that has many small, dark spots.
A freckled object has small spots on its surface.
cobwebbed: Cobwebbed material is usually old and dusty.
A "cobwebbed" thing is usually covered in dust and spider webs.
honeycombed: Honeycombed material looks like a series of hexagonal shapes laid out in a honeycomb pattern.
A honeycombed material looks like a series of hexagons or honeycombs.
woven: Woven material looks like a piece of fabric with a weave pattern.
A woven pattern looks like a fabric that has been woven together.
matted: A matted thing can look like it is tangled, or like it has a lot of small knots.
A "matted" object is one that is tangled or stuck together.
zigzagged: A "zigzagged" thing looks like a line that goes back and forth, rather than going in a straight line.
A zigzagged object has a Pointed, zigzag shape.
marbled: A marbled pattern is usually created by combining two different colors of clay together to create a swirled effect.
A marbled object has a surface that is marked with streaks or swirls of different colors.
studded: Studded patterns are created by adding small metal studs to a fabric.
A studded texture is one that has a lot of small bumps or "studs" on it.
grid: A grid texture is a repeating pattern of squares that are aligned in a grid.
A grid texture typically looks like a series of evenly spaced horizontal and vertical lines.
